text: (upbeat music) - Dobo, welcome to the show.

- Glad to be here. Thank you. - Glad to have you here. So for those of you who
don't know you, who is Dobo,

and what has your data
journey been like so far? - All right. My name is Dobo Radichkov.

I'm the chief data officer
at Holland & Barrett. My journey with data
probably started a while ago.
I grew up in Bulgaria. Growing up, I was a maths geek. And when I was 18, I moved to the US

and I studied computer engineering. And I wanted to get into
the space where I could use

some of that engineering
geekness that I had, but also work with difficult

or challenging business problems. So when I graduated, I
joined a analytics company,

analytics consultancy called
Cannondale Associates, which was later acquired by
Kantar Retail, part of WPP.

And for the first few years, that was an amazing opportunity because we worked with
large quantities of data

way before we had big
data and cloud and AI and all of that stuff.

We had big machine
servers in the basement. We were running, you
know, complicated queries
on hundreds of millions of data points and loyalty card data from large
CPG retailers and manufacturers in the US. And it was exciting,
because it took 20 minutes to run a query. And so you had to make sure you actually write a pretty good query.

And then you can go off
and play a game of chess and then you come back and
look at the results, right? - Like this whole punch card computing.
- Well, not quite like that. So this was 2004, right? So relatively still modern times,

but, you know, before cloud was there. And so, you know, today
we're spoiled, right?
You can run queries in seconds and get the insights instantly, and you can just go really, really fast.

But that's when I really,
really got excited about data analytics in general

and kind of bringing that
technical, you know, geeky side, the scientific part of
it, the engineering,

with the application of that to solve, you know,
difficult business problems. 'Cause in the end of the
day, we were consultancies,

so we were consulting,
putting together, you know, presentations and
recommendations and proposals

and using the insights
from the data, you know, to help our clients.
So that kind of set the direction of my, you know, professional journey.
I did that for five years in the US. I moved back to the UK in 2000,
or moved to the UK in 2009. I completed master's in business.

And then I did consulting
for a few more years. And then I decided I've
done enough consulting

for a lifetime. And I moved into like a
pure tech role, right? So I joined a company called OLX, which is

a global classifieds operator. So for those of us that
may not be familiar,

similar to eBay or Craigslist
in the US or Gumtree here.

- Or dubizzle.
- Or dubizzle in Dubai. Yeah. And so, you know,

the scale of that business
was just mind-boggling, right? At the peak, we had half a
billion monthly active users,

and operating in markets like Brazil, India, large
Southeast Asia markets,

Europe, Sub-Saharan Africa,
Latin America, right? So it was just really, really exciting.

And this was in 2014, right? Again, it was relatively
early in the cloud journey.
A lot of companies were still on-premise and were coming on the cloud.

and for the next seven, eight years, that was the journey for me. And that's when my journey
with AWS also started, right?

So we built all of the central kind of data infrastructure
and architecture
and platforming on AWS. And yeah, I'm sure we'll chat about that

in a bit more detail later, but that was super exciting. So I had an opportunity to work
with really fantastic teams,

very, very talented, building that stuff. And then about three years
ago I moved to the UK.

I returned to the UK again. And I've been with Holland
& Barrett since late 2021,

where I look after the data team, the central data and
analytics organization.

And that's the end-to-end sort of spectrum from data engineering,
the very technical stuff

to data warehousing, analytics,
data science, and BI.

And it's been super exciting. We're part of a big
digital transformation.
The data topic is very important, and a big part of the strategy of the H&B

digital transformation journey. And three years later we're still here and growing that team
and stronger than ever,
and very close partners with AWS as well. - Very interesting journey. I definitely want to drill down more

on the transformation
you're having in H&B. But before that, I mean,
this has been, what,

20-year journey or so? - Yeah, about 20 years now. - So I think you mentioned
some very important things
that demystify a little bit the journey towards becoming a chief data officer.
And I think a lot of people these days are aspiring to understand how can I break into data analytics?
How do I become an ML engineer? How do I get into this world? And a lot of it is, of course,

making the right moves at the right time, and depending on your skills
and the available technology.

What advice, in terms of
making the right moves,

would you give to a young, aspiring, ambitious go-getter now? Would you recommend consultancy
first as a foundation?

Would it be taking a
software engineering role? Would it be straight
into data engineering? What would you recommend?

- Honestly, I don't
think there's one path. I think it's more the end
goal that is important, right?

So you kind of want to be, and again, my journey is very
personal, very individual,

but there's probably many
different ways to get to the role.
Data itself is very diverse, right? So within my area,
my team deals with extremely technical engineering heavy topics.

And then we deal also with, parts of the team deals with
very business-facing topics.
And so data in itself is quite a wide function and topic and capability.

And then I think, in addition to data, you kind of have to have
that business orientation.

Because typically, with the job, what you need to do is
interface with the business
to understand their needs and translate that to, you know, the capabilities and the strategy,

the data strategy that
you're gonna put in place and execute on. So, you know, if you
can't do that very well,
that's not a great place to be in, right? So there's kind of two extremes. You can be very, very technical

and focus on the engineering, and that's, you know, a great place to be, or you could be very close to
the business side of things

and the strategy and kind of
the operating side of things. And I think there has to
be a sweet spot with data,

because you kind of need
to tap into both worlds from time to time.
- Sure.
- And, you know, I've worked with a lot of different types of data professionals, and there's no sort of one person alike.

There's always like a unique
journey and unique story. But my advice would be, you know, try to build that broad profile, you know?

You have to be passionate
about the engineering side. You have to be passionate
about the analytics. You have to be passionate about
visualization, data science,

and also the business strategy. Like, all of these things
kind of have to come together.

And, you know, if that's not
the case, then that's fine. You could have a very successful career just on the engineering side.

But if you're passionate
about the broader spectrum, then I think, you know, that can take you on that more kind of CDO journey.

- Do you feel like, you know, coming from a heavy math and computer engineering background, that working in consultancy
served as a forcing function

but actually, we need a business case, we need an ROI, we need to work
backwards from the customer, otherwise this thing is just
not gonna see the light of day.

- Yeah, so, I mean, you could get, you know, very much
addicted to building stuff

without actually having, of course, like an outcome or an impact. So it's very important to
always go back to the vision,

the strategy, you know, what
you're trying to achieve. I think, to answer your
question, consulting

is a great discipline, and I recommend to a lot of
people to just give it a go

and see if it's something that you enjoy. Maybe you do it for a few years, maybe you do it for longer, right? Who knows. But the things that
consultancy can teach you

are things like
storytelling, communication, structure, frameworking,
relating to clients,

understanding their needs, you know? Those are very valuable
skills in any context, whether it's data or not.

So definitely I think that
that part of my journey has helped me quite a
lot throughout the years.

- Excellent. Excellent. So let's tie that into
what you're doing now

at Holland & Barrett. What were the lessons that
you learned from, you know, all of that experience that you've had,

that you applied in Holland & Barrett, especially starting with
where was it when you started

and where are we now? And if you could take us through that journey and the learnings, that would be great. - Yeah.
- Yeah.
- So where did the story start? So again, I joined three years ago. The digital transformation journey for H&B

started a little bit earlier. And just, you know, in terms of context, H&B is a very well-known
UK staple brand, right?
Been around for 150 years. We have

more than a thousand stores in the UK, and in total 1,300-plus
stores across Europe.

So it's a pretty large-scale organization. But it also comes from a place
where it's quite traditional.

So the digital transformation
journey that we are on aims to modernize our business.

And that looks at things
like data, obviously, technology, product, customer-centricity,

omnichannel, bringing
that retail experience across both offline and online channels,
international expansion and so on. And additional services beyond the traditional kind of retail.
So all of that is very ambitious, and it's a very energizing mission to kind of be part of, because our mission

is to make wellness a
way of life for everyone. And so I think when I
came in three years ago,

that was a couple of
years into the journey. And I think that it was a time

where we kind of needed to, we'd spend a bit of time
building the foundations
of our data capabilities, but I would say probably they were not very consistent and clear,

and perhaps not very future-proof. So the journey started
by defining, you know,
what is that data strategy? What does data mean for H&B? What do we want to achieve with data?

It's all good to say we need data, but what does that actually mean? And then splitting that
into different capabilities,

hiring the teams behind those, reorganizing where we have to reorganize, establishing some new
tech where, for example,

we didn't have a data warehouse, right? So that's quite an
important aspect to have as part of a data platform.

So we added that into the
strategy and we executed on that. And we have a great data
warehousing team today.

And so really our journey is about, we call it data is the beating
heart of the business, right?
And we kind of have to make decisions through data on a daily basis.
You know, that's the beating heart, the rhythm of the business. And we started from a fairly, I would say,

humble starting point, but I'm very proud and happy
with where we are today. And big shout-out to the team

that has made it possible as well. And yeah, it's been really exciting. - So to get a bit tangible
here about, you know,

how to get this done, where did you start? Did you start like, okay,
we need a data strategy. Let's go top-down.

Did you go more like
bottom-up, like, okay, there are some foundations
we need to build; let's build the foundations first,
and then use that scaffolding to let the team run with the requirements?
Or is it more of a consulting approach where we do an analysis or an assessment

of here's where we are now, and we give the a score for each kind of element
of a data platform

and where we need to be, and then the steps we need
to achieve each of them. Or neither of these three options?
Or what approach did you take? - That's a really good question. I mean, in any C-role,
in my kind of CDO role as I came in, you kind of have a limited time window to have that early impact.

And there's a lot of
expectations, obviously. So I think it's very important. It's quite critical
how you spend your time
in the first, you know, couple of months. And usually, you know, in my experience,
as you join a business, typically there's like three, you know, three kind of approaches, right?

Either that's build something from scratch if it's, you know, a business
without a data platform

or without any kind of data
capability in our team. Or you're there to kind
of pivot or transform
what was already there. Or you're coming in to kind of enhance and build on what's already there.
And so for us, it was the second, right? So there was capabilities in place,
but we had to tweak them, right? We had to pivot certain things, we had to stop doing certain things and we had to start doing other things.

So the first few weeks was
really about making that clear by understanding the existing stack,
the existing capabilities, auditing, so to say, what was in place.

And then working with the team, you know, to create that vision
of what the new platform

and the new strategy will look like. - Okay, so it's more about finding, really finding out where are
we now and what's the delta

between now and where
we want to be, right? But how did you define
where do we want to be.

Because sometimes the
different parts of the business have an idea of where they want to be
from a business outcome perspective in terms of use cases, revenue, bottom line, whatever it is;

from the technical perspective, where we want to be
means using modern tools, using modern tech, maybe
automating processes.

You are the bridge that
brings that all together to crystallize the definition of where do we want to be. How did you go about that?

- Yeah, it's a really good question again. I mean, so with data, it's not something that you can extract benefit
from overnight, right?

It's a journey. And that's quite important
to explain to the business and to the leadership
and to tell that story.
And so you have to be very mindful about what the ultimate business goal is

and the value that
you're trying to create. But you also have to
take certain investments

in the short term that are
more technical in nature, that you know that you're gonna have to do one way or the other,
regardless of the use cases.

And that's just an investment
that you need to do. And usually my approach
would be to communicate

to the management team that
the first 3 to 6 months, it's going to be a lot
of investment, right? You're not gonna see a
lot of visible output,
because that will come later, right? So it's about laying that foundation. And especially if you are turning around

existing capabilities or you're starting from
scratch, obviously. But you kind of have to
time-box that, right?

That needs to be a 3- to 6-month exercise. If it starts to take a
bit longer, you know,

your credibility will have an impact, Your reputation, people
will start to get impatient.

They will want to start to see some, they would want to start
to see some results.

And so, you know, what we did was expectation settings. So we said, "Okay, we're
gonna take six months
to build a new platform." So that involved enhancing the existing data lake,
and also building a data warehouse, because we didn't have one, and we used Redshift for that, AWS.

And in that period, a lot of it was learning
about the business, establishing the relationships,

but also building that foundation,
building that platform. And then focusing on a
couple of quick wins, because you do have to
show a few quick wins

even though the platform
may not be fully ready, just to keep the momentum and
to keep the excitement going.

So in that first, you
know, six-month period, it was all about expectation management,

articulating the vision, getting the buy-in from leadership, and then, you know, executing
really well on that.

Execution is extremely important as well. - I think you mentioned
something very important, which is time-boxing.

me personally, I've worked
with many organizations and who have been trying
to build out, you know,

a new data strategy,
data platform, whatever. And I could tell you that they've almost never
met their timelines, right?

And for good reasons.
- Yeah. - You said 3 to 6 months,
which is quite ambitious.

I've seen some organizations
take 6 to 12 months
just to evaluate technology, just to define where do we want to go, just to align stakeholders,

just to set up MVPs and POCs. So just the decision, just
the defining what we want

and the decision-making process
could take 12 to 18 months.

How were you able to time-box all of this and balance the short
term with the long term

in 3 to 6 months? And how could other people do the same? - Yeah, again, good
question. And you're right.

Like, I've spoken to folks who, you know, two, three years later, they're still building
the platform, right?
And that is not an unusual scenario. And it can be very challenging.

I think, in our case, so what helped was that I'd
done that a few times, right?

And by the time I joined H&B, I probably deployed five
or six data platforms
in different contexts, large-scale, small-scale startups to kind of global enterprise.
And so when you've done that a few times, you develop a playbook. And every time you refine that playbook,

you make it a little bit better. You learn a little bit
more about, you know, the mistakes that you've made and what to do and what not to do.

And so, you know, essentially, building on that experience,
it was relatively,

the decision-making I think
was relatively quick, right? So within a few weeks,

we kind of knew what the
stack should look like. And again, I don't want to discredit
what was already there, right? We already had a data lake and we had a lot of data in place. So we didn't start from, you know, zero.
We had something in place. But what you're saying is interesting,
because when I came in, actually, a lot of the last year prior to that was spent doing proof of concepts

and experimenting with different options and evaluating different options. And I think when you
have too many choices,
you kind of get this decision paralysis- - Paradox choice, kind of thing. - You know, paradox of choice. Yeah. It's too many choices.

They all do things
similarly but differently, you know, which one is better. And there's pricing, and
then there's like features

and you start comparing all the features. And they're all tools in
the end of the day, right? And you could probably make
it work with any of them.

So, you know, my kind
of perspective on this is that, you know, learn
one of those tools well,

really, really well, and just build that expertise and keep learning and
building on top of it.

So in our case, you know, I've worked with Redshift since 2014. And I think Redshift came out
in 2013 or something, right?
So it was pretty early on in the journey.

And, you know, Redshift
has been part of my career and professional journey since then.

And it's been an essential part of, you know, whatever
progress and success I've seen.

So yeah, I have to also
be thankful to, you know, the great tech that AWS has built.

And again, there's alternatives, and you can make it work with others, but that's what works for us. And I think very quickly
we made the decision,

and then we just started
executing the playbook, and also bringing the team.

You kind of have to hire
a few strategic roles, perhaps from your network that you know,

that you can bring from
your past experience, and then start to grow that
knowledge in the playbook

across the whole team. And over time, you know,
you managed to do that. - How did you break the team
out of analysis paralysis

and get them to let's make a decision. Maybe it's imperfect, but
we need to make a decision.
At the end of the day, they are tools, like you were saying. - By being very unpopular, I think. So usually, I think- - Hey, that's a good point, actually.

If we're trying to please everybody, you're gonna please nobody, right? - Yeah, you tend to make
people a little bit upset

at the start, because they're
kind of used to what's there. No one likes change. They like the tech that
they have, you know.

And they've invested
emotionally into it, right? If somebody were to come in tomorrow and says we're gonna get
rid of what you've got
and start something new, I'd be very upset as well. And that's happened a few times, right?
And you kind of have to, I guess you need to balance the empathy,

but also really focus on
what's right for the business. And you might lose a few
people along the way,
and that's unfortunate. That's their decision, but in the end of the day, you gotta do what's right for the business

and also what you believe is right for the team longer term.
- Yeah. - And so, yeah, I think,

with a new role, with a new C-level role, there's always that initial period where you can afford to
be disruptive, right?

There's an expectation
that things will change. So you can do that. You can't do that every six months,

'cause then you will burn out the team, and it will destabilize
the whole operation.

But you have that two-,
three-month window, initial time window where you can assess,

audit, articulate what
you think is working, what isn't working,
and what has to change. And then you work with the team

to bring them on board with your vision. And that bringing on board
is also very, very important.

They have to be bought into it. And so that's kind of what we did. - Okay.
- Yeah.

- So if I were to distill
some of the learnings that you mentioned here,

you come in, because you're new, you know that people are going
to expect some disruption.

So you lean into that,
into the initial period, to make as many changes as possible, risking some unpopularity,

but probably it's the best time for it. At the same time, we
time-box certain activities

so that we give the business just enough to give us leeway to do
the long-term investments

that we need to make while giving them some quick wins.
- Wins. Yeah. - And at the same time

hiring some of the strategic
roles from your network, or growing them from within,
if the talent is available. And then use all of these elements

to build out the foundations that you need to make the most progress
to cover that delta

that we mentioned earlier. And then we are now into
business as usual and execution. Does that summarize it well?
- Fantastic summary. Yes.

- Okay. Great. - Except you don't end
up to business as usual, 'cause that never comes.

- Ah, there's no such thing, right? - It's just phase 1, what
I would call phase 1. - Right. Right.
- Yeah. - You know, that's actually a good point.

I think we all have this
idea in our mind sometimes. I mean, I don't want
to speak for everyone,
but at least from personal experience, there is this collective idea that there is a cruising altitude

stage that we'll reach, which could be true for some elements. But it's never really true
for everything, is it?

So I think about it, thinking about it in a phased approach is more useful as a mental
model than business as usual,

like you were saying. - Yeah. I mean, the way
we think about it is, so we think of our data strategy
as a roughly five-year journey. So we're kind of three years in now. And phase 1 is that building phase, right?

So it's about getting
the platform in place, hiring the team, structuring the team,
putting a robust organization in place. And so that's the initial investment.

And that phase is
actually really exciting, because you get to build stuff
and you get to build a team, and you're kind of like coding with them.
And, you know, it's exciting. It's also tiring, but it's exciting. And then what I would call phase 2

is then when you kind
of start scaling that; so you take that foundation

and you start getting value out of it. So you're growing usage,
you're growing adoption,

you're spreading the
analytics in the business. So you get more and more people to have access to data and insights.

You demonstrate value in terms of making the right decisions. You build some tools,
you build some, you know,

customer-facing features
and things like that, right? So you're kind of really
scaling on the foundation

now it's really about
extracting the value out of it. So it's translating data into P&L impact,
into initiatives, into tangible results, part of business initiatives.

And that's also very exciting. And it's probably equally
difficult as the earlier phases.

You're no longer like
building from scratch. So, you know, maybe phase 1

is more entrepreneurial in some sense, but you're focused on
sustaining and making sure

that the platform accommodates
the growth of the business, and continuously delivering
return on that investment.
And you generally don't have a lot of ROI conversations in year one. But you have a lot of them later on,

because the scrutiny increases and the expectation levels of, you know, the returns on the
investments that you've put
into the team and the data also increase. And that's kind of where we are now.

- So three phases. Phase 1, foundation building. Phase 2, scaling. Phase 3, translating
into business outcomes.

- Yeah.
- Right. How did that map to the three-year
or the five-year journey? Like, from a timeline perspective?

Okay, but understand it
on an abstract level, what the phases are, but on the ground, how
did that translate from- - I would roughly map it
to year one is phase 1,

year two is phase 2, and
maybe year and a half. And then the last three years
of the journey is phase 3.

- Okay, how do you make sure that you're able to
meet timelines like that if there is a big gap somewhere

in The initial audit that you've done. The gap doesn't necessarily
have to be technology. It could be technical debt.

It could be software
engineering practices. It can definitely be talent,

either availability of
talent or skills of talent or distribution of talent. Like, you don't have them
in your org, for example.

They could be spread out across different orgs or different departments
within the same org.

So how do you manage
that kind of situation? - Yeah, so I think you hit
the nail on the head, right?

So if you look at what makes
a data strategy successful,
you have the tech, you have the people, you have the ways of working.
And I would add to that the culture of the company.
And so we kind of look at all those four. And I would say for the tech we're okay.

It's never gonna be perfect, but it's a pretty strong stock, and we're happy with it
and we're scaling it.

People-wise, you mentioned
concentration of talent, right? So we try to find the talent
wherever they are, right?

I have team members in my team that are in Indonesia
and Argentina, right? So we're covering almost like,

I mean, definitely more
than half of the globe. And we have people all all over, right?
And these are folks that, you know, we've just found, you know, in some cases we knew them from before,
but in some cases we just, you know, look for the best people, and that's where we found them. So our mindset is, you know,

find the best talent no
matter where they are. And these days it's easier
with remote working; it's a lot easier to get that done.

And then you've got
kind of ways of working. So we are a very
product-centric organization

in terms of the whole technology function, and also increasingly more
the rest of the business.
And so it's about, you know, being agile, being experiment-driven, data-driven,
you know, not having huge waterfall plans. And sprint-based, quick feedback loops,

customer insights and that sort of thing. So, you know, best-in-class
engineering practices, really.

We apply that. And then culture I think is interesting, and that's probably the
most challenging one,
I would say, still, because culture takes time. - And you can't see it, right? You can't measure it.

- You can kind of feel it.
- You have to feel it. - Yeah, you can feel it. And how do you define it in one, right? It's not easy to define-

- True, true.
- culture. But you can kind of feel it in the efficiency of the
business in terms of behaviors,

in terms of perhaps, I don't know, some
outcomes that are not ideal
but shouldn't have been there. And that takes time. And that's more than data, you know.

That almost touches on the
broad people culture aspect. And I think for somebody in my role,
you know, kind of my responsibility is to champion data

and to help evangelize to the business how we should operate
and how we should behave

and how we should use data
on a day-to-day basis; almost like beyond the tech,
but on a cultural level.

And that's a journey,
right? That takes time. And we're still working on it. And I'm sure we will stumble a few times

before we get it right. But we're definitely moving
in the right direction. - So I think culture
is an important aspect.

Sometimes it's not
well-understood or well-defined. But we all know that it's
there; it has a part to play.

So I want to understand
how you manage the culture. First of all, how did you
change the perceptions of stakeholders? In the sense that data's not a function,

but it is something that
needs to be part of a culture. We need to become a data-driven
culture on one hand.

And on the other hand, given that remote work
has made work easier,

some would argue that it also
makes culture harder to scale. So how do you manage or scale the culture

to get people feeling the
same resonance frequency, so to speak, in Indonesia and Argentina
as the people here in the UK? - I'll start with the second question. So yeah, it's a very correct observation.

And that's something I
also really miss, right? So some of my best
experiences professionally

was when we had a small
capable team in one place,
you know, kind of having that entrepreneurial family feeling. And you're working on difficult problems

and you're kind of winning
or failing together, right? That's a really special feeling to have.

And it's an amazing thing
when you get that right. And so sometimes I miss that, because,
as you said, when you're working remotely, it's quite difficult to replicate that.

You don't have those intangible,
informal life interactions.

You kind of become a face on the screen. And unfortunately, that's
the reality, right?

I don't think that will change. So we kind of have to bring
the best of both worlds. So I think there's certain
benefits of remote working,

obviously, but like
